clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Metformin in Pre-frail Elderly
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized-Controlled Trial of Metformin to Prevent Frailty in Pre-frail Elderly

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to investigate the effects of metformin to prevent frailty in pre-frail non-diabetic elderly. Several outcomes measured in this study are frailty status, quality of life, handgrip strength, gait speed, and serum myostatin levels.
We hypothesize that metformin for 16 weeks could prevent frailty in pre-frail elderly.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in frailty status at 16 weeks

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in health-related quality of life (HrQoL) at 16 weeks
Change from baseline in handgrip strength at 16 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Measurement: handgrip dynamometer (Jamar Hydraulic Hand Dynamometer Model J00105)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in gait speed at 16 weeks
Change from baseline in serum myostatin levels at 16 weeks

arm_group.description: Metformin tablet 500 mg three times a day for 16 weeks.
Placebo tablet three times a day for 16 weeks.

intervention.description: Metformin tablet 500 mg three times a day for 16 weeks. If there is no significant outcome obtained between two arms in 16 weeks, metformin will continue until 24 weeks.
Placebo three times a day for 16 weeks. If there is no significant outcome obtained between two arms in 16 weeks, placebo will continue until 24 weeks.
